column1: Jelcz-Laskowice [ˈjɛlt͡ʂ laskɔˈvʲit͡sɛ] is a town in Oława County
column3: in south-western Poland. It is the seat of the administrative district (gmina) called Gmina Jelcz-Laskowice. It lies on the Odra (Oder) river
column4: approximately 12 kilometres (7 mi) north of Oława
column5: and 24 kilometres (15 mi) south-east of the regional capital Wrocław. As of 2019
column6: the town has a population of 15

column1: The town was created on January 1
column2: 1987 as a union of the former municipalities of Jelcz (German: Jeltsch) and Laskowice (Laskowitz). It was best known for its large bus factory
column3: owned by the company Jelcz S.A.
column4: though since the bankruptcy of that company the largest employers have been Toyota and the Mechanical Institute.

column1: The oldest traces of human settlement in present-day Jelcz-Laskowice date back to the Neolithic period.In the Middle Ages both Jelcz and Laskowice were part of the Kingdom of Poland ruled by the Piast dynasty. The first known mentions of both villages come from the 13th century
column2: although they probably already existed in the 12th century. Laskowice was first mentioned in 1203
column3: when it was granted by Duke Henry the Bearded to Polish noble Leonard Włostowic
column4: the grandson of Piotr Włostowic. Jelcz was first mentioned as Jalche in a 1245 deed
column5: when Pope Innocent IV assigned it to the Archdiocese of Wrocław. In 1277 Duke Bolesław II the Bald of Legnica here captured and arrested his nephew Duke Henryk IV Probus of Wrocław. Bolesław's grandson
column6: Duke Bolesław III the Generous had a castle erected on an island in the Oder river about 1331. The village of Laskowice
column8: was reestablished in 1293 in a slightly different location by Duke Henry V.

column1: From 1871 to 1945 the area was part of Germany
column4: the nearby hamlet of Miłoszyce was the site of the Fünfteichen subcamp of the Nazi German Gross-Rosen concentration camp
column5: where forced labourers built 145 mm (6 in) howitzers for the Berthawerke
column6: a branch of the German Krupp company. Testing grounds still feature concrete installations 2 km (1.2 miles) east of the village of Nowy Dwór. Howitzers were hauled on rails from the branch Berthakrupp via Laskowice
column7: Piekary and north of Nowy Dwór. Since 1945 Soviets sent over 160 railway sorties
column8: presumably to Smolensk leaving very little behind them.

column1: In 1945 the area according to the results of the Potsdam Conference became again part of Poland. In 1949 Polish Ministry of Defense began the production of Mobile Repair Vehicles and Ambulances for military purpose. Bus production by Jelcz S.A. started in 1952.
